ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual discussion and guest lectures.
Class discussions and written assignments.
Virtual guest speakers
In-person lecture, live, recorded
Zoom sessions with writing tutor
None

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In this course, I developed the following skills: close reading texts, making clear topic sentences, forming a complicated thesis and claim.
I improved my writing and analysis skills.
This class was helpful in fine tuning my writing skills and further developing my close reading abilities.

I have learned so much and am very grateful for Professor Baynes-Ross. I learned how to close read efficiently and convey ideas more effectively. Ive learned how to communiate more direct starting from my introduction, tranistions and conclusions.  Ive learned how to oay attention to detail and how to expand possibilites on one small detail.
Better ways of understanding readings and to put my thoughts on paper
I sharpened my ability to write argumentative and analytical papers with new techniques and improved writers craft.
Better writing skills
How to pull a deeper meaning through text and write as a Yale student

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The beginning of the course could be improved by incorporating more diverse authors for reading, which occurred in the end of the course. Discussions were not always engaging even though there were engaging prompts, which ultimately came down to a lack of community in the classroom. Strengths included the opportunity to meet with the professor individually for help and feedback with writing, in addition to the opportunity to do a research paper.

The strengths of this course come from the peer to peer and instructor to peer feedback. The weaknesses of this course stem from inconsistencies in topics and on format and the lack of communication about expectations. There were often miscommunications about what was expected and how it should be done.

Strengths live meetings and class disscusions, even breakout rooms, this kept me engaged and focused when it was hard. Having to discuss and ask questions about the previous weeks readings allowed me to stay up to date. 

Weaknessidk
The professor did a good job with letting students know the expectations of each essay and how they could improve. Readings were also interesting and of appropriate length.

Strengths: interesting topics with a wide range of perspectives 

Weaknesses: lack of student engagement
It was a really good course and I have no complaints about it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual discussions could have been improved by a stronger sense of the community in the class, which may have happened if we took time each class to check in with every person. I did this in other courses and found that it made a large difference in group discussion. Guest lectures were very engaging!
The pacing of the course was well paced. The deadlines were also very accommodating because the instructor took note of the happenings in Yale College, in relation to the pandemic.
They were all conducted well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend English 114 to another student, but not this specific section, only because the topic of rebels, outcasts, and heretics was less engaging than I hoped it would be. I really enjoyed when we were able to choose our own moments of rebellion to analyze, and I wish that the course had included more social rebellion with people of color and women.
The course material is very interesting. The ideas discussed are very relevant to social issues even today.

I think the title of this course is a little misleading. I think it portrays it as three different categories that will be discussed and that are intertwined, but we seemed to only discuss rebellion with little mention of the other two. I may or may not recommend this course to another student.

Yes This is a great introductory english writing course at Yale. Topic is very interesting and challeneges you to rethink the way we see rebels and rebellion. Also the professor is very patient and caring. Professor Baynes-Ross gives positive feedback for you to improve and understands her students.
Yes, the teacher and the class was great

If you appreciate writing about rebellion and feel passionately about a particular instance in history or a current issue dealing with rebellion, take it. If not, then this course might be too taxing and unenjoyable to do well in, especially within the context of a heavy courseload.
Yes, it was a very interesting class for writing credit
Yes I would recommend this course to All because they need to know how you should write at Yale.
